TopicTitle: Energomach's testbed for world's most powerful rocket engines

Articles.Content:
I want to share link to picture heavy report from unauthorized visit to Energomash testbed where world most powerful engines ([RD-170](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RD-170), [RD-180](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RD-180), RD-264) were tested.

[http://lana-sator.livejournal.com/160176.html](http://lana-sator.livejournal.com/160176.html)

Few picture to gain attention:

![290095_original.jpg](http://ic.pics.livejournal.com/zelenyikot/65139567/290095/290095_original.jpg)

This enormus chimney towers are used to disperse rocket motor's exhaust high into air becouse facility is located in populated ares ([here](http://wikimapia.org/#lang=ru&lat=55.916115&lon=37.445902&z=17&m=b)). This is how it looks then on full power:

![0_71e83_5dfd0bfb_XXL.jpg](http://img-fotki.yandex.ru/get/2/33213654.df/0_71e83_5dfd0bfb_XXL.jpg)

Btw it is very, very kerbal idea to build testbed for rocket engines on toxic components (in 1960-1970 Energomash's specialization was N2O4-UDMH engines for ICBM and space. Notably Proton's [RD-275](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RD-253)) near contry's most populated city.

That's "fox tail" in the plume. It indicates presence of high quantities of nitrogen oxides in the exhaust. Specifically, nitrogen dioxide is the gas that gives it that red/brown color. Which means that they are still running tests with highly toxic fuels, like hydrazine variations and nitrogen tetroxide. And that means enormous environmental damage to the area. Smokestack or not, nitrogen dioxide gets captured by humidity in the air and percipetates very easily as acid rain/fog. Same goes for a number of other chemicals I'd expect in that plume, and they have even worse effects on environment and health.
